Package software.leonov.common.io

Class Fs

  • java.lang.Object
    • software.leonov.common.io.Fs
  • public final class Fs
extends Object
    Static utility methods for working with Files and Paths.

    The class is not intended to substitute the functionality in java.nio.file.Files, com.google.common.io.MoreFiles, or com.google.common.io.Files. The intent is to provide unified access between various Java and Guava I/O classes to some of the most commonly used I/O operations.

    Warning: The java.io.File facility does not scale with large file systems, suffers from race conditions, and provides no platform-independent way to detect symbolic links. As such there is no way to ensure a symbolic link to a directory is not followed when traversing a file tree. In the presence of symbolic links, you may encounter files outside the starting directory, or even end up in an infinite loop.

    Note: While java.io.File operations are not deprecated, Java 7+ users are highly encouraged to use java.nio.file.Path operations introduced in JDK 7 as part of the The Java NIO.2 File System.

    The following tables describe common convenience methods provided by this class and their closest Guava and Java equivalents:

     append(byte[], Path)MoreFiles.asByteSink(Path, CREATE, APPEND).write(byte[])Files.write(Path, byte[], CREATE, APPEND)
   
    
   
    
     append(CharSequence, Path)MoreFiles.asCharSink(Path, UTF_8, CREATE, APPEND).write(CharSequence)Files.write(Path, CharSequence.toString().getBytes(UTF_8), CREATE, APPEND)
    Java 11 equivalent: Files.writeString(Path, CharSequence, CREATE, APPEND)

                          File to)
                   throws IOException
        Appends bytes to the given file.

        If the file does not exist it will be created.

        Parameters:
        bytes - the bytes to append
        to - the file write to
        Returns:
        the given file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

        public static void deleteDirectoryContents​(File dir)
                                    throws IOException
        Deletes all the files within a directory. Does not delete the directory itself.
        Parameters:
        dir - the directory to delete the contents of
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the argument is not a directory
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • getChecksum

        public static long getChecksum​(File file,
                               Checksum checksum)
                        throws IOException
        Deprecated.
        Users not working with legacy APIs should prefer hash(File, Hashing.crc32()).padToLong() or hash(File, Hashing.adler32()).padToLong() which uses Guava's Hashing facility.
        Computes and returns the checksum value of the given file using the specified checksum object.

        The Checksum is reset when this method returns successfully.

        Parameters:
        file - the given file
        checksum - the specified checksum object
        Returns:
        the result of Checksum.getValue() for all the bytes in the given file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • getDigest

        public static byte[] getDigest​(File file,
                               MessageDigest digest)
                        throws IOException
        Deprecated.
        Users not working with legacy APIs should prefer hash(File, HashFunction) which uses Guava's Hashing facility.
        Computes and returns the digest value of the given file using the specified message digest object.

        Invoke MessageDigests.toString(byte[]) to get a lower case hexadecimal string representation of the digest value which conveniently matches the output of Unix-like commands such as md5sum.

        The MessageDigest is reset when this method returns successfully.

        Parameters:
        file - the given file
        digest - the specified message digest object
        Returns:
        the result of MessageDigest.digest() for all the bytes in the given file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • getName

        public static String getName​(String path)
        Returns the last name in the path's name sequence. This method does not validate the specified path.

        This method handles both Windows and Unix path separator characters.

        Parameters:
        path - the specified path
        Returns:
        the last name in the path's name sequence
        See Also:
        Files.getNameWithoutExtension(String), Files.getFileExtension(String), MoreFiles.getNameWithoutExtension(Path), MoreFiles.getFileExtension(Path)

      • getNameWithoutExtension

        public static String getNameWithoutExtension​(String path)
        Returns the filename without its file extension or path. If the path is empty and empty string is returned.
        Parameters:
        path - path the specified path
        Returns:
        the filename without its file extension or path

      • hash

        public static HashCode hash​(File file,
                            HashFunction func)
                     throws IOException
        Computes and returns the HashCode of the given file using the specified hash function.

        Invoke HashCode.asBytes() to get the hash code value as a byte array or HashCode.toString() for a lower case hexadecimal string representation which conveniently matches the output of Unix-like commands such as md5sum.

        Parameters:
        file - the specified file
        func - the given hash function
        Returns:
        the HashCode of the given file using the specified hash function
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

        a new BufferedWriter which writes to the given file using the UTF-8 charset
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • walkFileTree

        public static File walkFileTree​(File start,
                                FileWalker<?> walker)
                         throws IOException
        Walks a file tree. This method walks a file tree rooted at a given starting file. The file tree traversal is depth-first with the given FileWalker invoked for each file encountered. File tree traversal completes when all accessible files in the tree have been visited, or a visit method returns VisitResult.TERMINATE.

        If the file is not a directory then the visitFile(File) is invoked. If the file is a directory, and the directory could not be opened, then the visitFileFailed(File, IOException) method is invoked with the I/O exception, after which, the file tree walk continues, by default, at the next sibling of the directory.

        If the directory is opened successfully, then the entries in the directory, and their descendants are visited. If an entry is deleted before it is visited the visitFileFailed(File, IOException) method is invoked with a FileNotFoundException. When all entries have been visited then the postVisitDirectory(File) method is invoked. The file tree walk then continues, by default, at the next sibling of the directory.

        When a security manager is installed and it denies access to a file (or directory), then it is ignored and the FileWalker is not invoked for that file (or directory).

        Warning: While this method is not deprecated users not working with legacy APIs are encouraged to switch to JDK 7+ and use Files.walkFileTree(Path, FileVisitor) in the The Java NIO.2 File System.

        The java.io.File facility provides no platform-independent way to detect symbolic links, as such there is no way to ensure a symbolic link to a directory is not followed when traversing a file tree. In the presence of symbolic links, you may encounter files outside the starting directory, or even end up in an infinite loop.

        Parameters:
        start - the starting file
        walker - the FileWalker instance to invoke for each file
        Returns:
        the starting file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs
        IllegalArgumentException - if the starting file does not exist

      • walkFileTree

        public static File walkFileTree​(File start,
                                int maxDepth,
                                FileWalker<?> walker)
                         throws IOException
        Walks a file tree. This method walks a file tree rooted at a given starting file. The file tree traversal is depth-first with the given FileWalker invoked for each file encountered. File tree traversal completes when all accessible files in the tree have been visited, or a visit method returns VisitResult.TERMINATE.

        If the file is not a directory, then the visitFile(File) method is invoked. If the file is a directory, and the directory could not be opened, then the visitFileFailed(File, IOException) method is invoked with the I/O exception, after which, the file tree walk continues.

        If the directory is opened successfully, then the entries in the directory, and their descendants are visited. If an entry is deleted before it is visited, then the visitFileFailed(File, IOException) method is invoked with a FileNotFoundException. When all entries have been visited then the postVisitDirectory(File) method is invoked. The file tree walk then continues.

        The maxDepth parameter is the maximum number of levels of directories to visit. A value of 0 means that only the starting file is visited, unless denied by the security manager. A value of MAX_VALUE may be used to indicate that all levels should be visited.

        When a security manager is installed and it denies access to a file (or directory), then it is ignored and the FileWalker is not invoked for that file (or directory).

        Warning: While this method is not deprecated users not working with legacy APIs are encouraged to switch to JDK 7+ and use Files.walkFileTree(Path, Set, int, FileVisitor) in the The Java NIO.2 File System.

        The java.io.File facility provides no platform-independent way to detect symbolic links, as such there is no way to ensure a symbolic link to a directory is not followed when traversing a file tree. In the presence of symbolic links, you may encounter files outside the starting directory, or even end up in an infinite loop.

        Parameters:
        start - the starting file
        maxDepth - the maximum number of directory levels to visit
        walker - the FileWalker instance to invoke for each file
        Returns:
        the starting file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs
        IllegalArgumentException - if the starting file does not exist

      • createParentDirectories

        public static Path createParentDirectories​(Path path,
                                           FileAttribute<?>... attrs)
                                    throws IOException
        Creates any necessary but nonexistent parent directories of the specified path.

        The attrs parameter is optional file-attributes to set when creating the nonexistent directories. Each file attribute is identified by its name. If more than one attribute of the same name is included in the array then all but the last occurrence is ignored.

        This method is identical to MoreFiles.createParentDirectories(Path, FileAttribute...) save for returning the target directory which allows for method chaining.

        For example: java.nio.file.Files.copy(from, Fs.createParentDirectories(to));

        Note: If all parent directories exist calling this method is a no-op. If this operation fails because of an I/O error or other problems it may have succeeded in creating some (but not all) of the parent directories.

        Parameters:
        path - the path whose parent directories will be created
        attrs - an optional list of file attributes to set atomically when creating the directories
        Returns:
        the the path whose parent directories have been created
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • createDirectories

        public static Path createDirectories​(Path path,
                                     FileAttribute<?>... attrs)
                              throws IOException
        Creates a directory by creating all nonexistent parent directories first. Unlike the Files.createDirectory(Path, FileAttribute...) method, an exception is not thrown if the directory could not be created because it already exists.

        The attrs parameter is optional file-attributes to set when creating the nonexistent directories. Each file attribute is identified by its name. If more than one attribute of the same name is included in the array then all but the last occurrence is ignored.

        The nearly identical Files.createDirectories(Path, FileAttribute...) method bizarrely fails if the path already exists, but is a symlink to a directory. While in the strict sense this does not violate the API Documentation which states a FileAlreadyExistsException will be thrown if the path exists but is not a directory, it is completely counter intuitive, since Files.isDirectory(Path) will return true when a symlink references a directory. This method provides the same functionality but will not fail if the path is a symlink to the target directory.

        Note: If the target directory and all its parent directories exist calling this method is a no-op. If this operation fails because of an I/O error or other problems it may have succeeded in creating some (but not all) of the parent directories.

        Parameters:
        path - the directory to create
        attrs - an optional list of file attributes to set atomically when creating the directory
        Returns:
        the created directory
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • getChecksum

        public static long getChecksum​(Path path,
                               Checksum checksum)
                        throws IOException
        Deprecated.
        Users not working with legacy APIs should prefer hash(Path, Hashing.crc32()).padToLong() or hash(Path, Hashing.adler32()).padToLong() which uses Guava's Hashing facility.
        Computes and returns the checksum value of the given file using the specified checksum object.

        The Checksum is reset when this method returns successfully.

        Parameters:
        path - the given file
        checksum - the specified checksum object
        Returns:
        the result of Checksum.getValue() for all the bytes in the given file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • getDigest

        public static byte[] getDigest​(Path path,
                               MessageDigest digest)
                        throws IOException
        Deprecated.
        Users not working with legacy APIs should prefer hash(Path, HashFunction) which uses Guava's Hashing facility.
        Computes and returns the digest value of the given file using the specified message digest object.

        Invoke MessageDigests.toString(byte[]) to get a lower case hexadecimal string representation of the digest value which conveniently matches the output of Unix-like commands such as md5sum.

        The MessageDigest is reset when this method returns successfully.

        Parameters:
        path - the given file
        digest - the specified message digest object
        Returns:
        the result of MessageDigest.digest() for all the bytes in the given file
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • hash

        public static HashCode hash​(Path path,
                            HashFunction func)
                     throws IOException
        Computes and returns the HashCode of the given file using the specified hash function.

        Invoke HashCode.asBytes() to get the hash code value as a byte array or HashCode.toString() for a lower case hexadecimal string representation which conveniently matches the output of Unix-like commands such as md5sum.

        Parameters:
        path - the specified file
        func - the given hash function
        Returns:
        the HashCode of the given file using the specified hash function
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs
